explanation:
Correct calculation: \(10 \times 4 \times 5 = 200\ \mathrm{cm}^3\)
Student's calculation: \(10 + 4 + 5 = 19\ \mathrm{cm}^3\)

The student applied addition to all three dimensions instead of multiplication. The error stems from confusing the volume formula (which requires multiplying all dimensions) with a linear measurement. This substitution of summation for the required product directly reduced the three-dimensional calculation to a one-dimensional sum. The error is distinct from mixing area/volume (which would involve multiplying only two dimensions) or partial multiplication, as all terms were included in the incorrect operation. The presence of \(\mathrm{cm}^3\) units shows recognition of volume measurement, eliminating unit-related misconceptions.
